 This has proven incredibly ineffective. One study on "abstinence pledges" showed that the rate of STD infections for kids who pledged abstinence was equivalent to those who didn't make the pledge. BUT kids who pledged abstinence were MORE LIKELY to engage in oral and anal sex as a way of "maintaining" their "virginity". They were ALSO more likely to not use a condom if they did violate their abstinence pledge.

 Teaching abstinence only is just not working. I'm working to substantiate this claim, but Penn & Teller's show stated that eleven states had tried to validate that their "abstinence only" programs had helped with teen-age pregnancy and STD prevention. NONE of them could show any improvement.
 
 If we want to fight HIV, we have to do more than just tell kids "no". It just doesn't work. And it's demeaning to our kids...
 Give them ALL the information available, and let THEM make THEIR OWN decisions for themselves.
 
 Of course, if the parent wants their child not to receive all the info, they can pull their kid from the class. Perhaps put out two classes, with one being "abstinence only" and another giving all the options. (Although I think that last option is a little mundane...)

In other words, I don't think STDs are the primary reason for abstinence pledges at all (even if they, in some cases, claim that it is.)
